segments.text: Dorian Gray’s eyes fixed steadily on his servant as he entered the room. Dorian wondered, almost imperceptibly, if the man had secretly peered behind the screen. The servant remained impassive, waiting silently for his orders while Dorian lit a cigarette and walked over to the glass. In the reflection he saw Victor’s face—a placid mask of servility—reminding him that appearances could be deceiving, and that caution was always necessary.
Tell the house-keeper that I want to see her, and then go to the frame-maker and ask him to send two of his men round at once.
As his servant departed, Dorian’s gaze wandered to the glass where Victor’s image, unchanging yet laden with an undercurrent of menace, remained. A subtle unease crept in despite the calm exterior.
Moments later, Mrs. Leaf, dressed in a black silk gown and wearing old-fashioned thread mittens, bustled into the library. Her aged hands trembled as she prepared to serve him.
The old schoolroom, Mr. Dorian? Why, it’s full of dust. I must get it arranged and put straight before you go into it. It is not fit for you to see, sir. It is not, indeed!

voice_traits.pronunciation: deliberate, with a touch of tremor

segments.text: I don’t want it put straight, Leaf. I only want the key.

voice_traits.pacing: even, with a hint of irritation

segments.text: Well, sir, you’ll be covered with cobwebs if you go into it. Why, it hasn’t been opened for nearly five years – not since his lordship died.

voice_traits.pacing: measured yet slightly quick due to anxiety

segments.text: That does not matter. I simply want to see the place – that is all. Give me the key.

voice_traits.pacing: steady, with heavy emphasis on finality
voice_traits.emotion: cold, with a hint of resentment

segments.text: And here is the key, sir. I’ll have it off the bunch in a moment. But you don’t think of living up there, sir, and you so comfortable here?

voice_traits.pauses: deliberate, as if weighing every word
voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: old-world etiquette evident in her speech

segments.text: No, no. Thank you, Leaf. That will do.

Mrs. Leaf lingered for a few moments, chatting idly about household details. Dorian sighed, dismissing her chatter with a vague gesture to manage things as she saw fit. Once she left, Dorian slipped the key into his pocket. His eyes then fell upon a large, purple satin coverlet, heavily embroidered with gold—a splendid piece of late seventeenth-century Venetian work his grandfather once prized. He mused darkly that this very coverlet, once used as a pall for the dead, would now serve to conceal something equally dreadful—a corruption far worse than death itself.

His thoughts drifted to memories of his grandfather and regretfully recalled how Basil might have helped him resist Lord Henry’s influence. Dorian’s inner monologue revealed the conflict between a noble, intellectual love for Basil and the poisonous temptations that now ruled his fate. It was too late for redemption; the future, rife with forbidden passions and haunting dreams, was inevitable.

Clutching the opulent coverlet, Dorian moved behind the screen to face the portrait. He examined it intently—gold hair, blue eyes, and rose-red lips remained unchanged, but the expression had become cruelly altered. It was as if his own soul stared back, accusing him. Overwhelmed by disgust, Dorian flung the rich pall over the picture just as a knock sounded at the door.
The persons are here, Monsieur.

voice_traits.tone: measured, with a hint of treachery in his choice of words
voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: slightly formal with an undercurrent of slyness

segments.text: Wait for an answer and show the men in here.

voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: staccato commands that leave no room for argument

segments.text: Within minutes, Mr. Hubbard, the celebrated frame-maker from South Audley Street, arrived along with a rough young assistant. Hubbard, with his florid red whiskered face and fat, freckled hands, exuded both charm and the perennial frustration of dealing with impecunious artists.

What can I do for you, Mr. Gray? I thought I’d do myself the honour of coming round in person. I have just acquired a beauty of a frame – an old Florentine piece from Fonthill, eminently suited for a religious subject.

voice_traits.tone: enthusiastic, with a hint of self-importance

segments.text: I am so sorry you went to the trouble, Mr. Hubbard. I shall certainly drop in to view the frame another time – though religious art isn’t my usual pursuit. Today, however, I only require your help in carrying a picture to the top of the house. It’s rather heavy, so I’d ask you to lend a couple of your men.

voice_traits.pauses: strategic, causing slight emphasis on the request

segments.text: No trouble at all, Mr. Gray. I am delighted to be of service. Which work of art are we moving, sir?
This.

voice_traits.emotion: secretive, with an edge of menace
voice_traits.pauses: a noticeable pause as he reveals the object
voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: short, clipped statement that carries ominous weight

segments.text: There will be no difficulty, sir. I’ll have my assistant unhook it from these brass chains. And now, where shall we carry it?

voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: businesslike with hints of artistic flair

segments.text: I’ll show you the way, Mr. Hubbard. Please follow me – we’ll take the front staircase; it’s wider, and the picture is rather bulky.

voice_traits.pauses: a pause after the instruction adds gravity

segments.text: Dorian led Mr. Hubbard and his assistant from the door, up the front staircase. Despite Mr. Hubbard’s periodic protests about a gentleman doing useful work, Dorian found himself lending a hand with the cumbersome frame. Upon reaching the top landing, the little frame-maker grunted, 'Something of a load to carry, sir,' as he wiped his shiny forehead. Dorian merely murmured his acknowledgment while unlocking the door to a room that had seen little use in years—an almost forgotten study from his childhood.

Inside the spacious, well-proportioned room built by his great-uncaring grandfather, every detail stirred the echoes of his youth: the huge Italian cassone, the satinwood book-case crammed with old schoolbooks, and the faded Flemish tapestry. These relics of a purer, boyish past now served as the perfect hideaway for the portrait—a portrait that carried the ever-growing burden of his soul’s corruption. Dorian justified his act by convincing himself that no one would ever see the cursed image again, not even his own eyes.
Bring it in, Mr. Hubbard, please. I’m sorry for keeping you so long.

voice_traits.pacing: measured, as though weighed down by thought

segments.text: Might one look at the work of art, sir?

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause before the question

segments.text: It would not interest you, Mr. Hubbard.

voice_traits.pauses: almost none, delivered in one swift statement

segments.text: Not at all, Mr. Gray. Ever ready to do anything for you, sir.

After Mr. Hubbard and his assistant departed, their footsteps faded into the background. Dorian listened to the sound of the house settling. He then secured the secret room with the key, ensuring that no curious eye would ever lay upon the portrait—only his, a constant reminder of his shame. Meanwhile, returning to the library just after five o’clock, he noticed that tea had been served. On a small, dark perfumed table lay a note from Lord Henry and a tattered yellow-bound book—a thoughtful present from Lady Radley. Alongside, a copy of the third edition of The St. James’s Gazette sat as if heralding another twist in his carefully concealed life.

Dorian’s eyes fell upon Lord Henry’s note: a brief instruction mentioning the evening paper and a meeting set for eight-fifteen at the club. As he perused The St. James’s Gazette, a red pencil mark on the fifth page caught his eye with a chilling report about an inquest into Sibyl Vane—a young actress now declared dead by misadventure. With a frown of distaste and disgust, he tore the marked page in two and flung the pieces aside, cursing the vulgarity of reality and the implication that Victor might have known more than he dared admit.

His attention then shifted back to the yellow book sent by Lord Henry. On a delicate, pearl-coloured octagonal stand, the volume beckoned him. Seated in a worn arm-chair, Dorian became lost in its strange, hypnotic prose—a tale of sensual ecstasy, mysticism, and the shifting moral landscapes of centuries past. The text wove a tapestry of dreamlike imagery and dark introspection, making him forget the passage of time until even the fading daylight and a solitary star could be seen through the window.

At length, his valet’s gentle reminders of the late hour coaxed him from his reverie. He rose, left the library, and dressed for dinner before setting out to the club. There, in the early evening, he found Lord Henry seated alone in the morning-room, looking most bored.

segments.emotion: apologetic, with a trace of self-reproach
segments.text: I am so sorry, Harry, but really it is entirely your fault. That book you sent me so fascinated me that I completely lost track of time.

voice_traits.emotion: apologetic with an undercurrent of wonder
voice_traits.pauses: a deliberate pause after ‘Harry’ and before the confession
voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: marked by refined articulation and subtle irony

segments.text: Yes, I thought you would like it.

voice_traits.emotion: amused, with a hint of condescension
voice_traits.pauses: short, allowing for a measured delivery
voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: inflected with wit and a touch of nonchalance

segments.text: I didn’t say I liked it, Harry. I said it fascinated me. There is a great difference.

voice_traits.emotion: intensely serious with a hint of reproach
voice_traits.pauses: strategic, particularly before emphasizing the difference

segments.text: Ah, you have discovered that?

voice_traits.pauses: a subtle pause after the question for effect
voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: a touch of ironic playfulness in his speech

segments.text: With that, the two men left the morning-room and passed into the dining-room, marking the end of a day steeped in secrets, brooding introspection, and the unspoken promise of hidden sins. The chapter closed on the tableau of refined conversation and dark musings, leaving the secret of the portrait and its corrupted beauty safe for yet another day.
